Metal-organic framework (MOF)-derived hollow metal oxides exhibit significant potential as cutting-edge electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) owing to their exceptional intrinsic activity, expansive specific surface area, structured controllability, and adjustable pore dimensions. Nevertheless, their industrial utilization faces the obstacles such as intricate synthesis procedures, limited scalability, and inconsistent performance, necessitating the formulation of effective solutions. Various engineering strategies have been proposed by researchers to tackle these hurdles. This comprehensive review highlights recent breakthroughs in engineering MOF-derived hollow metal oxides and their applications in electrocatalytic OER. It initiates by juxtaposing the drawbacks of traditional metal oxides against the advantages of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. Subsequently, it delves into a thorough exploration of the engineering methodologies employed to elevate their OER efficiency. Lastly, the review delineates current challenges and potential avenues for the development of more efficient MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts in the future. Graphical Abstract Keywords Metal-organic framework Hollow Metal oxide Electrocatalytic Oxygen evolution reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Electrochemical water splitting is an alternative to the methane steam reforming for green hydrogen production [1]. However, the water splitting efficiency is closely associated with a core process, anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) that is initiated at the boundary of multiple phases [2,3]. As is well-known, the OER involves the oxidation of water molecules to generate oxygen gas, protons, and electrons. Developing cost-effective catalysts for the OER is crucial for advancing sustainable energy conversion systems [4]. To optimize industrial water splitting for hydrogen production, the strategic design of the reaction interface for the OER, involving high-performance electrocatalysts to significantly reduce overpotential, enhance reaction kinetics, and improve efficiency, is of utmost importance [5–7]. Presently, benchmark OER catalysts consist of Ir and Ru-based materials, extensively researched and utilized to enhance OER electrocatalysis. However, Ir and Ru, being noble metals, encounter various challenges in the OER domain. On one hand, the high cost of Ir and Ru, as noble metals, results in elevated production expenses for large-scale applications. Additionally, the rarity of Ir and Ru as metals with limited resources may present difficulties in meeting extensive demand. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of Ir and Ru in the OER can be influenced by environmental conditions and catalyst structure, potentially leading to instability [8,9]. Moreover, under specific OER conditions, Ir and Ru may be prone to corrosion, impacting their catalytic performance and stability [10–12]. To tackle these challenges, researchers are actively exploring alternative materials or enhancing catalyst structures to boost the efficiency and stability of the OER, reduce costs, and lessen dependence on scarce resources [13,14]. Among various nonnoble metal materials, transition metal oxides (TMOs) offer a diverse range of options for OER catalysts, with varying levels of activity, stability, and cost [15–19]. Continued research and development in this area are essential for advancing the use of TMOs in OER for sustainable energy applications. However, there are still some primary drawbacks, such as limited active site, poor electrical conductivity, and strong binding strength with oxygen intermediates [20,21]. To this end, enormous endeavors have been dedicated to the exploration of effective strategies to address these issues. In recent years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as promising precursors for the fabrication of hollow metal oxides with potential applications in the OER [22–26]. MOF-derived hollow metal oxides present distinct advantages for OER catalysis. Firstly, these materials typically exhibit a high surface area, providing a plethora of active sites for OER catalysis [27–30]. Additionally, the structure and composition of MOFs can be precisely tailored to engineer hollow metal oxides with specific properties, such as pore size, surface area, and metal composition, enabling fine-tuning of OER performance [31–35]. Furthermore, the hollow architecture of these materials facilitates the diffusion of reactants and products, enhancing mass transport and overall catalytic efficiency [36–38]. Nonetheless, certain drawbacks persist, including synthesis complexity, limited scalability, and performance variability [39]. Continuous research and development efforts are imperative to address these challenges and fully unleash the potential of these materials for sustainable energy applications. Consequently, significant strides have been made in the modification and optimization of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides to enhance the electrocatalytic OER performance, resulting in the successful development of numerous high-performance catalysts in this category. In this review, we summarize the recent advances of the regulation strategies for MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts ( Scheme 1). The review started with the advantages of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. Then, we conducted an in-depth discussion about the engineering strategies used to improve the OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides, which included the morphology and architecture design, heteroatom doping, defect engineering, interface engineering, integrating with conductive substrate or isolated metal sites. Finally, the review is ended with a summary of current challenges for MOF-derived hollow metal oxides electrocatalysts for OER and point out some possible opportunities for the future designing of highly efficient TMO-based electrocatalysts. 2 Synthesis of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides MOFs are versatile materials that have a high surface area, tunable porosity, and unique structural properties. The unique properties of MOFs make them excellent precursors for the synthesis of hollow metal oxides with controlled morphology, high metal content, and tunable properties, enabling them ideal materials for a wide range of applications in catalysis, energy storage, and sensing. There are several common methods for converting MOFs into hollow metal oxides. The first one is the template-assisted synthesis [40]. In this method, a sacrificial template is used to create a hollow structure within the MOF. The template is then removed, leaving behind a hollow structure that can be converted into a metal oxide. The second one is the chemical etching that involves selectively removing the metal ions from the MOF structure using a chemical etchant [41]. This results in the formation of a hollow structure that can be further converted into a metal oxide. Thirdly, thermal decomposition is also a widely employed method for converting MOFs into hollow metal oxides. By heating the MOF at high temperatures, the organic ligands are removed, leaving behind a hollow metal oxide structure [42]. Fourth, the sol-gel method is also an effective strategy for realizing the successful construction of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. In this method, the MOF is dissolved in a solvent to form a gel-like material. The gel is then dried and calcined to form a hollow metal oxide structure. With the rapid development of electrochemical technology, the electrochemical conversion is also highly favorable for the synthesis of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. These are just a few of the common methods for converting MOFs into hollow metal oxides. Each method has its own advantages and limitations, so it is important to choose the most suitable method based on the specific requirements of the desired metal oxide structure. 3 Advantages of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides Metal oxide electrocatalysts have demonstrated significant promise for the OER in a variety of energy conversion and storage devices. Nonetheless, there are certain drawbacks associated with the use of metal oxide electrocatalysts for the OER. In comparison to conventional metal oxide electrocatalysts, MOF-derived hollow metal oxides offer notable advantages ( Scheme 2). Firstly, MOF-derived hollow metal oxides typically boast a high surface area, providing a greater number of active sites for facilitating the OER. This can result in heightened catalytic activity and enhanced efficiency [43–45]. Secondly, the hollow structure of MOF-derived metal oxides enables improved mass transport of reactants and products, along with efficient gas diffusion, leading to accelerated reaction kinetics and enhanced performance [46]. Additionally, the composition, structure, and morphology of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can be readily adjusted by selecting the metal precursor, MOF template, and synthesis conditions. This customization allows for the optimization of the material's properties for OER applications [47]. Furthermore, MOF-derived hollow metal oxides may exhibit enhanced stability and durability owing to their well-defined structure and composition, resulting in extended operational lifetimes and improved long-term performance [48,49]. It has also been noted that the synthesis of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can be cost-effective, particularly when compared to alternative synthetic approaches for producing high-performance OER catalysts, making them more accessible for large-scale deployment [50–52]. Although the great advantages, the industrial applications of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide catalysts also encounter a bottleneck, and some challenges should also be overcome, such as the low acidic OER activity, limited understanding of the structure-activity relationship of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides for the OER, limited structural stability under harsh operating conditions, and poor electrical conductivity. 4 Strategies for enhancing the electrocatalytic OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide 4.1 Morphology and architecture design The morphology and architecture design of electrocatalysts play a crucial role in determining their performance for OER [53]. The design of the catalyst's structure can significantly impact its surface area, active sites, mass transport, and electronic properties, all of which are critical for efficient electrocatalysis [54–57]. For TMOs, the morphology and architecture design are particularly important as they can impact the exposure of active sites, the diffusion of reactants and products, and the conductivity of material [58–60]. Different morphologies such as nanowires [61,62], nanosheets [63,64], hollow structures [65], or porous architectures can offer distinct advantages in terms of catalytic activity and stability [66,67]. While the significance of morphology and architecture in catalytic performance is widely acknowledged, current strategies for enhancing the efficacy of TMOs face certain limitations. These constraints may encompass challenges in accurately manipulating morphology, struggles in attaining high surface area or active site density, and difficulties in optimizing electronic and structural properties. Overcoming these challenges necessitates the advancement of innovative synthesis techniques and sophisticated characterization methods to precisely govern the morphology and architecture of TMO-based electrocatalysts. Furthermore, a profound comprehension of the structure-activity relationship and the fundamental mechanisms dictating electrocatalytic performance is imperative for surmounting existing bottlenecks and achieving further advancements in catalytic efficiency. Inspired by this, enormous endeavors have also been made to substantially improve the electrocatalytic OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides via morphology and architecture design. For instance, Han et al. synthesized a novel Ni-Co Prussian-blue-analog (PBA) nanocages consisting of pyramidal walls and employed them as precursors to synthesize the bimetallic Ni-Co oxide nanocages via annealing in air ( Fig. 1 a-j) [68]. Impressively, the derived bimetallic Ni-Co oxide nanocages could show high electrocatalytic activity and extraordinary electrochemical stability toward the OER. The distinctive 3D open structure of bimetallic Ni-Co oxide nanocages possessed the advantages of 3D surface molecular accessibility, which not only allowed the exposure of more active sites, but also ensured the access of electrolyze to both the internal and external surfaces, thereby accounting for the enhanced OER activity and durability (Fig. 1 k, l). Jiao and coworkers constructed the multi-shelled Mn-Co oxide hollow dodecahedra (Co/Mn-HD) with near 3 shells via a controlled calcination of the Mn-doped ZIF-67 precursor ( Fig. 2a) [69]. It is found that the distinctive multi-shelled and polycrystalline structure with porous channels not only provides a very large electrochemically active surface area, but also enhances the structural stability of the material (Fig. 2b-g). More importantly, the residual C and N in the final structures also benefit for the enhanced electrical conductivity, which confirm the great significant of morphology and architecture design for achieving extraordinary electrocatalytic OER performance. 4.2 Heteroatom doping The electrocatalytic performance of metal oxides for the OER can be significantly enhanced through heteroatom doping. This process involves the introduction of heteroatoms into the metal oxide lattice, which can yield several advantageous effects on its OER activity [70–72]. One of the key effects is the alteration of the metal oxide's electronic structure. For instance, nitrogen doping can generate new electronic states within the metal oxide's band gap, thereby enhancing charge transfer properties and catalytic activity [73–75]. This can lower the overpotential required for the OER and boost the overall efficiency of the electrocatalyst. Moreover, heteroatom doping can induce the formation of defects and active sites on the metal oxide surface, facilitating the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules and improving reaction kinetics [76,77]. Additionally, heteroatom doping can bolster the stability and durability of metal oxide electrocatalysts by mitigating surface corrosion and the aggregation of active sites, crucial for ensuring prolonged OER performance and practical utility [78]. Thus, heteroatom doping has emerged as a promising strategy to enhance the OER performance of metal oxide electrocatalysts. Building on this, the heteroatom doping strategy has been proposed for the modification and optimization of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides to achieve extraordinary electrocatalytic OER performance. For instance, Zhang and colleagues have investigated the significant impact of heteroatom doping on the electrocatalytic OER performance of Co3O4 [79]. Specifically, they have reported on a cooperative etching-coordination-reorganization strategy for the introduction and stabilization of isolated metal atoms in hierarchical hollow Co3O4 nanoplates ( Fig. 3a). The novel ZIF-67 nanoplates were used as precursors, and a guest metal salt was employed as a Lewis acid to induce the transformation of solid nanoplates into a hollow structure with unique cross-channels (Fig. 3b-e). Benefiting from the unique structural and compositional merits, the hierarchical hollow nanoplate structure exhibited superior OER activity with an ultralow overpotential of merely 262 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2, alongside extraordinary electrochemical stability. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations revealed that the adsorption energy difference from OH* to *O was also greatly decreased after Fe doping, which accounted for the enhanced OER activity. Importantly, this strategy can be universal for the synthesis of a series of M-ZIF-67 nanoplates and corresponding M-Co3O4 hollow nanoplates (M = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Zr, Nb, W, In, Sn, Bi, and La) (Fig. 3f). Later, a unique heterostructured inter-doped ruthenium-cobalt oxide [(Ru-Co)Ox] hollow nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth is synthesized to deliver outstanding electrocatalytic OER performance ( Fig. 4a-d) [80]. As a consequence, the extremely low overpotentials of 44.1 mV and 171.2 mV are required to deliver 10 mA cm−2 for HER (Fig. 4e) and OER (Fig. 4f), respectively. It is discovered that the heteroatom doping can modify the electronic structure of metal oxide to optimize the binding strength with intermediates (Fig. 4g). Owing to the desirable compositional and structural merits of more exposed active sites and optimized electronic structure, such (Ru-Co)Ox can display an optimized binding energy with oxygen-involving intermediates, thereby exhibiting outstanding electrocatalytic OER and HER performance. 4.3 Polymetallic oxides Polymetallic oxides have shown significant potential as efficient electrocatalysts for the OER, a critical process in various electrochemical applications such as water splitting and rechargeable metal-air batteries [81,82]. The unique properties of polymetallic oxides make them promising candidates for catalyzing OER. One of the key effects of polymetallic oxides is their ability to provide multiple active sites for OER [83]. The presence of multiple metal cations in the oxide structure allows for a strong synergistic effect, where the combination of different metal ions can enhance the overall electrocatalytic activity [84]. This can lead to the improved OER kinetics, lower overpotentials, and increased reaction rates compared to single-metal oxides. Additionally, the electronic structure of polymetallic oxides can be tuned by varying the composition and oxidation states of the metal cations, which can further enhance their OER activity [85]. The presence of different metal ions can facilitate the electron transfer during the OER, leading to improved catalytic performance. Polymetallic oxides have been applied in a range of electrochemical devices, such as water electrolyzers, demonstrating encouraging performance in facilitating efficient and sustainable hydrogen production. Moreover, they have been employed in metal-air batteries to improve the OER kinetics and enhance overall battery performance. The resilience and endurance of polymetallic oxides in OER conditions render them well-suited position for practical utilization. Their capacity to endure challenging electrochemical environments is vital for ensuring prolonged operational stability in electrochemical devices. For example, Qian and coworkers reported a versatile method based on the anion-exchange reaction with FeCo-MIL-88B to synthesize a series of amorphous mixed metal oxide hollow nanoprisms ( Fig. 5a), including the FeCoWOx, FeCoVOx, FeCoPOx, FeCoBOx and FeCoSeOx (Fig. 5b-e) [86]. Benefitting from the strong synergistic contribution of mixed metal sites and the unique hollow nanoframe, such polymetallic metal oxides could deliver outstanding OER performance (Fig. 5f-h). More recently, NiCo2-xFexO4 polymetallic nanoboxes were also developed via a MOF-engaged strategy by Lou and coworkers to deliver outstanding electrocatalytic OER ( Fig. 6a-g) [87]. It is documented that the strong synergistic effect of trimetallic component contributes to the enhanced OER performance. In addition, the unique hollow nanobox structure ensures the full contact of active sites with electrolyte and boost the electron and mass transport. Benefitting from these merits, such NiCo2-xFexO4 polymetallic nanoboxes could deliver superior OER activity, with an extremely low overpotential of merely 274 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6h-j) and outstanding electrochemical stability. In summary, polymetallic oxides have shown a significant effect as efficient electrocatalysts for OER, with their ability to provide multiple active sites, tunable electronic structures, and excellent stability. Further research and development in this area are expected to lead to the advancement of electrochemical technologies for sustainable energy conversion and storage. 4.4 Defect engineering Defects in metal oxides play a crucial role in shaping their electrocatalytic performance in the OER [88,89]. The presence of defects can bring about alterations in the electronic structure, surface chemistry, and catalytic activity of the metal oxide, thereby impacting its OER efficiency. One primary manner in which defects influence OER performance is by introducing additional active sites for the OER reaction to occur. Defects like oxygen vacancies or metal cation vacancies can serve as sites for oxygen adsorption and activation, facilitating the OER process [90]. Moreover, defects can alter the local electronic structure of the metal oxide, leading to variations in the binding energies of reaction intermediates and the overall OER kinetics [91]. Conversely, certain types of defects, such as surface hydroxyl groups or metal cation interstitials, can act as traps for reaction intermediates, impeding the OER process [92]. These defects can raise the energy barrier for OER intermediates to migrate and react, resulting in reduced catalytic activity. Furthermore, defects also impact the stability and durability of metal oxide electrocatalysts during the OER. For instance, specific defects may encourage the formation of surface oxides or hydroxides, which can shield the active sites from degradation and enhance the long-term stability of the catalyst [93]. In this regard, the introduction of defects in MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can significantly enhance the intrinsic OER activity. For instance, Wang and coworkers synthesized the ultralow Ru doped CoOx hollow nanobox catalyst through a facile MOF derivation strategy ( Fig. 7a) [94]. It is demonstrated that the hollow nanobox catalyst is existed with rich metal defects and oxygen vacancies, which benefit for the charge transfer and affording more catalytic active sites for intermediates during electrooxidation process (Fig. 7b-e). Endowed with the merits of hollow architecture of more active site, a large void space, and abundant oxygen vacancies, such hollow metal oxide catalyst can deliver superb electrocatalytic OER performance, with the overpotential of 265 mV to achieve 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7f, g). Later, Du’s group also synthesized the 3D open nanonetcage CoZnRuOx with both metal defects and oxygen vacancies through a simple in situ electrochemical etching method [95]. Their research found that the partial removal of ZnO through electrochemical etching can create multiple surface defects, which were favorable for the modification of local electronic structure and optimizing the interactions between active sites and intermediated species ( Fig. 8a-c). In addition, the creation of oxygen vacancies during annealing treatment also benefits for the substantial improvement in intrinsic OER activity. Upon the integration of these advantages, such CoZnRuOx nanonetcage catalyst can exhibit outstanding electrocatalytic OER performance. To achieve 10 mA cm−2, an ultralow overpotential of merely 244 mV is demanded (Fig. 8d). By integrating with commercial Pt/C for overall water splitting, a cell voltage of 1.52 V is required at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8e). Detailed mechanism study also reported that the Zn defect and oxygen vacancies can facilitate the OH- adsorption and charge transfer, accounting for the outstanding OER performance. In summary, defects in MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can have positive effects on their electrocatalytic OER performance. 4.5 Interface engineering Interface engineering plays a crucial role in enhancing the electrocatalytic OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. The interface between the metal oxide and other materials, such as carbon-based supports or conductive polymers, can significantly impact the catalytic activity, stability, and conductivity of the electrocatalyst [96,97]. By carefully tailoring the heterointerface, the electronic structure and surface properties of the metal oxide can be optimized to improve its OER performance [98,99]. For example, the introduction of carbon-based supports can enhance the conductivity of the metal oxide, leading to improved charge transfer kinetics and reduced overpotential for the OER [100]. Additionally, the interface engineering can also create active sites and promote the adsorption of reactants, further enhancing the catalytic activity of the metal oxide. Furthermore, interface engineering can also improve the stability of the MOF-derived hollow metal oxides by preventing aggregation or dissolution of the active metal species during the OER process [101]. This can be achieved by anchoring the metal oxide onto a stable support material or by introducing protective coatings to prevent corrosion or degradation of the catalyst. The Co3O4/NiCo2O4 double-shelled nanocages (DSNCs) were obtained by by synthesizing the ZIF-67/Ni-Co LDHs yolk-shelled structures followed by the in-situ transformation via annealing ( Fig. 9a-e) [102]. When used as electrocatalysts for OER, the heterostructured metal oxides can exhibit superior catalytic activity as compared to the single one, requiring the overpotential of merely 340 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 9f, d). According to the characterizations and electrochemical tests, it was discovered that the complex porous structure with a high specific surface area benefited for the electrocatalytic reactions. Moreover, the double-shelled structures can lead to the confinement of the electrolyte between the shells. Furthermore, the effective electron transfer according to the heterointerface and strong synergistic effect between Co3O4 and NiCo2O4 also accounted for the significantly enhanced OER performance. Besides metal oxide/metal oxide heterostructure, the interfacial engineering of metal oxide/other metal compound is also reported to be effective for the enhancement of electrocatalytic OER performance. For instance, Wang et al. constructed the Co3O4-Mo2N heterostructured nanoframes via the controllable pyrolysis of Mo-Co PBA ( Fig. 10a) [103]. It was reported that the Co3O4-Mo2N nanoframes not only inherited the functionalities of individual components and unique nanoframe structure (Fig. 10b-d), but also gave an ideal heterointerface with strong electron interaction and beneficial H2O/H* adsorption energies (Fig. 10e, f), thereby leading to extraordinary electrocatalytic OER performance (Fig. 10g-i). Overall, interface engineering plays a critical role in optimizing the electrocatalytic OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides by improving their electronic structure, surface properties, conductivity, and stability. This can lead to the development of highly efficient and durable electrocatalysts for various energy conversion and storage applications. 4.6 Combining MOF-derived hollow metal oxide with conductive substrates The combination of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide with other conductive substrates has shown promising results in enhancing the electrocatalytic activity for the OER. MOFs are a class of porous materials with high surface area and tunable chemical and structural properties, making them suitable precursors for the synthesis of metal oxides with unique nanostructures [104]. When combined with conductive substrates such as carbon materials or metal nanoparticles, MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can significantly improve the electrocatalytic performance for OER [105–108]. The hollow structure of the metal oxides provides a large surface area and abundant active sites, while the conductive substrates facilitate the electron transfer and improve the overall conductivity of the catalyst [109,110]. The application of these combined materials in OER electrocatalysis has potential implications for renewable energy technologies, such as water electrolysis and fuel cells. By efficiently catalyzing the OER, these materials contribute to the development of sustainable energy conversion and storage systems. For example, Zhang et al. synthesized the polyhedron-shaped yolk-shell structure that composed of Zn-Co-Ru ternary metal alloy oxide (ZnCo-RuO2/C) ( Fig. 11a) [111]. The yolk-shell structure of ZnCo-RuO2/C exposed abundant active sites and facilitated the mass transfer for OER (Fig. 11b-h). The ZnCo-RuO2 could exhibit high intrinsic OER activity, while the carbon substrate can display high electrical conductivity that may facilitate the electron transfer. Endowing with these favorable merits, such ZnCo-RuO2/C could display remarkably high OER activity, with an overpotential of merely 180 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 11i). Theoretical calculations uncovered that the ZnCo-RuO2 could dramatically decrease the energy barrier of the potential determining step, and the conductive substrate boost the charge transfer, both of which account for the enhanced OER performance (Fig. 11j, k). Thus, the combination of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides with other conductive substrates holds great promise for enhancing the electrocatalytic activity for OER and advancing the development of efficient and cost-effective energy conversion technologies. Further research and development in this area could lead to the commercialization of these materials for practical applications in the near future. 4.7 Combining hollow metal oxide with single-atom active site MOFs have gained significant attention as precursors for the synthesis of hollow metal oxide materials with unique properties. These hollow metal oxides have shown promising applications in various fields, including electrocatalysis. In recent years, the combination of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides with single-atom active sites has emerged as a novel approach for enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of these materials, particularly in the OER [112,113]. The integration of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides with single-atom active sites offers several advantages for improving the OER performance. Firstly, the hollow structure provides a high surface area and abundant exposed active sites, which can facilitate the transport of reactants and products during the electrocatalytic process. Additionally, the presence of single-atom active sites can enhance the intrinsic catalytic activity and durability of the material, leading to improved OER performance [114,115]. Furthermore, the integration of single-atom active sites with MOF-derived hollow metal oxides can significantly improve the electrical conductivity and also optimize the energy barrier [116–120]. The synthesis of hollow metal oxides with single-atom active sites typically involves a series of steps, including the preparation of the precursor, followed by controlled thermal decomposition or chemical transformation to generate the hollow metal oxide structure with well-dispersed single-atom active sites [121–126]. For example, Deng’s group reported the synthesis of Ir and Mo co-confined MOF-derived hollow nanobox by employing ZIF-67 as template to achieve high-performance OER electrocatalysts ( Fig. 12a-f) [127]. It is reported that an overpotential of merely 220 mV is demanded at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline solution (Fig. 12g, h). DFT calculation uncovered that the adjacent Mo and Ir isolated atomic sites synergistically improved the OER (Fig. 12i-l). In summary, the combination of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides with single-atom active sites represents a promising strategy for improving the electrocatalytic performance of materials for the OER [128]. Further research in this area is expected to lead to the development of highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts for various energy conversion and storage applications. 5 Challenges and perspectives OER is a key process for electrochemical water splitting used in hydrogen production and other energy conversion technologies. MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts show great potential in improving OER performance due to their unique structure and composition characteristics ( Table 1). In this review, we summarize the recent progress of engineering MOF-derived hollow metal oxides for serving as advanced OER electrocatalysts. We put emphasis on the engineering strategies used to improve the OER performance of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides, which include the morphology and architecture design, heteroatom doping, defect engineering, interface engineering, integrating with conductive substrate or isolated metal sites. After enormous endeavors devoted, their OER performance is substantially improved. However, there are still some challenges and future directions that need to be addressed to further improve its OER activity and stability. One challenge is to optimize the catalytic activity and stability of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts. Heteroatom doping, morphology and composition engineering and surface modification of active substances can effectively improve the performance of OER. However, the precise control of these factors and their synergistic effects on OER activity still need to be further explored. In addition, the scalability and cost-effectiveness of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts need to be addressed in practical applications. The development of scalable synthesis methods and the utilization of earth-rich and low-cost metal precursors are critical for the mass production of these electrocatalysts. Last but not least, most metal oxides derived from MOFs are obtained by calcination with low yields. Therefore, it is very important and urgent to explore new synthesis strategies to improve product yield and material preparation efficiency. In addition, the electrocatalytic properties of MOF-derived metal oxides are closely related to their structure. Excessive preparation parameters undoubtedly increase the difficulty of controlling product structure and shape. In terms of the future direction, the integration of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts with other functional materials, such as carbon-based support and conductive polymers, could further improve their OER performance and stability. In addition, the exploration of novel MOF structures and metal oxide compositions could expand the range of electrocatalysts with custom OER activity. Artificial intelligence and machine learning have shown great potential in aiding the selection and design of materials for various applications, including the synthesis of advanced metal oxide electrocatalysts using MOFs. These technologies can help researchers sift through vast amounts of data and optimize the selection of MOFs based on specific criteria such as catalytic activity, stability, and cost-effectiveness. In conclusion, the development of MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts for OER is a promising research direction and has great potential in advancing energy conversion technology. Addressing these challenges and exploring future directions could further improve OER performance and accelerate the practical application of these electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic framework (MOF)-derived hollow metal oxides exhibit significant potential as cutting-edge electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) owing to their exceptional intrinsic activity, expansive specific surface area, structured controllability, and adjustable pore dimensions. Nevertheless, their industrial utilization faces the obstacles such as intricate synthesis procedures, limited scalability, and inconsistent performance, necessitating the formulation of effective solutions. Various engineering strategies have been proposed by researchers to tackle these hurdles. This comprehensive review highlights recent breakthroughs in engineering MOF-derived hollow metal oxides and their applications in electrocatalytic OER. It initiates by juxtaposing the drawbacks of traditional metal oxides against the advantages of MOF-derived hollow metal oxides. Subsequently, it delves into a thorough exploration of the engineering methodologies employed to elevate their OER efficiency. Lastly, the review delineates current challenges and potential avenues for the development of more efficient MOF-derived hollow metal oxide electrocatalysts in the future.
